elements.content: Ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic alternating interactions within and between chains, respectively, were interpreted for a one-dimensional coordination polymer having high-spin (S = 5/2) MnII centers bridged by azido ligands, namely, [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n (bpm = bis(pyrazol-1-yl) methane).
elements.clean_text: Ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic alternating interactions within and between chains, respectively, were interpreted for a one-dimensional coordination polymer having high-spin (S = 5/2) MnII centers bridged by azido ligands, namely, [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n  (bpm = bis(pyrazol-1-yl) methane).

elements.content: The structural and magnetic properties of binuclear and polymetallic complexes with azido-bridged ligands have received considerable attention in the past three decades. From the magnetic point of view, the most interesting characteristic of azido-bridged complexes is that the azido ligand is a very effective superexchange pathway for its two main coordination modes and very effectively forms binuclear, tetranuclear, and one-, two-, and three-dimensional complexes, some of which show spontaneous magnetization at T c between 16 and 40 K. Exchange interactions between manganese(II) ions propagated through azido bridges are strongly dependent on the bridging modes of the N3 - ion. As is well-known, the azido ligand stabilizes either end-on or end-to-end coordination models when it links two manganese centers, giving ferro- or antiferromagnetic interactions, respectively, subject to certain restrictions on bond angles, torsion angles, and Mn−N bond distances. Specific magneto−structural correlations have been developed by Ruiz on the basis of hybrid density functional theory (DFT) methods and by Rojo on the basis of extended Hückel molecular orbital (EHMO) calculations. The results are somewhat different for the values of the Mn−N−Mn angles, which cause a crossover from ferro- to antiferromagnetism.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The structural and magnetic properties of binuclear and polymetallic complexes with azido-bridged ligands have received considerable attention in the past three decades. From the magnetic point of view, the most interesting characteristic of azido-bridged complexes is that the azido ligand is a very effective superexchange pathway for its two main coordination modes and very effectively forms binuclear, tetranuclear, and one-, two-, and three-dimensional complexes, some of which show spontaneous magnetization at T c between 16 and 40 K. Exchange interactions between manganese(II) ions propagated through azido bridges are strongly dependent on the bridging modes of the N3 - ion. As is well-known, the azido ligand stabilizes either end-on or end-to-end coordination models when it links two manganese centers, giving ferro- or antiferromagnetic interactions, respectively, subject to certain restrictions on bond angles, torsion angles, and Mn-N bond distances. Specific magneto-structural correlations have been developed by Ruiz on the basis of hybrid density functional theory (DFT) methods and by Rojo on the basis of extended Hückel molecular orbital (EHMO) calculations. The results are somewhat different for the values of the Mn-N-Mn angles, which cause a crossover from ferro- to antiferromagnetism.

elements.content: With the purpose of examining and investigating further magnetic interactions as a function of a one-dimensional chain complex, we succeeded in synthesizing the one-dimensional complex [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n , in which bpm is bis(pyrazol-1-yl)methane. Magnetic measurements indicate that, in agreement with the structural data, the chain shows a regular alternation of ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions and shows antiferromagnetic interactions in the interchains.
elements.clean_text: With the purpose of examining and investigating further magnetic interactions as a function of a one-dimensional chain complex, we succeeded in synthesizing the one-dimensional complex [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n , in which bpm is bis(pyrazol-1-yl)methane. Magnetic measurements indicate that, in agreement with the structural data, the chain shows a regular alternation of ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions and shows antiferromagnetic interactions in the interchains.

elements.content: Preparation of [Mn(bpm)(N 3 ) 2 ] n . A methanol solution of bpm (0.148 g, 1.0 mmol) was added dropwise to a mixture of manganese perchlorate hexahydrate (0.362 g, 1.0 mmol) and sodium azide (0.137 g, 2.1 mmol) in water−methanol (1:2, 20 mL). The final clear solution was kept at room temperature for 5 days to produce the complex as well-formed light-yellow crystals of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n , suitable for X-ray determination. Yield:  ca. 72%. Anal. Calcd for C14H16Mn2N20:  C, 29.28; H, 2.81; N, 48.78; Mn, 19.13. Found:  C, 29.42; H, 3.02; N, 48.40; Mn, 18.97.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Preparation of [Mn(bpm)(N  3  )  2  ]   n   . A methanol solution of bpm (0.148 g, 1.0 mmol) was added dropwise to a mixture of manganese perchlorate hexahydrate (0.362 g, 1.0 mmol) and sodium azide (0.137 g, 2.1 mmol) in water-methanol (1:2, 20 mL). The final clear solution was kept at room temperature for 5 days to produce the complex as well-formed light-yellow crystals of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n , suitable for X-ray determination. Yield: ca. 72%. Anal. Calcd for C14H16Mn2N20: C, 29.28; H, 2.81; N, 48.78; Mn, 19.13. Found: C, 29.42; H, 3.02; N, 48.40; Mn, 18.97.

elements.content: Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement of the Structure. The X-ray data for a single-crystal of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n having the approximate dimensions 0.30 × 0.35 × 0.40 mm were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.710 73 Å) radiation at room temperature. The crystallographic data, conditions restrained for the intensity data collection, and some features of the structure refinement are listed in Table . An ω−2θ scan mode was employed for collection of data in the range 4.5° ≤ θ ≤ 25°. A total of 2211 reflections was collected, and 1855 independent reflections (R int = 0.035) were considered for use in the succeeding refinement. The data were corrected for Lorentz−polarization and absorption effects (DIFABS9). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F using the SHELXTL-PC computer program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were located on calculated positions. The final refinement including hydrogen atoms converged to R = 0.040 and R w = 0.049. The number of refined parameters was 153. Maximum and minimum peaks in the final difference Fourier synthesis were 0.60 and −0.37 e·Å-3. Final atomic coordinates are reported in Table , and significant bond parameters are given in Table .
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement of the Structure. The X-ray data for a single-crystal of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n  having the approximate dimensions 0.30 × 0.35 × 0.40 mm were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The crystallographic data, conditions restrained for the intensity data collection, and some features of the structure refinement are listed in Table . An ω-2θ scan mode was employed for collection of data in the range 4.5° ≤ θ ≤ 25°. A total of 2211 reflections was collected, and 1855 independent reflections (R int = 0.035) were considered for use in the succeeding refinement. The data were corrected for Lorentz-polarization and absorption effects (DIFABS9). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F using the SHELXTL-PC computer program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were located on calculated positions. The final refinement including hydrogen atoms converged to R = 0.040 and R w = 0.049. The number of refined parameters was 153. Maximum and minimum peaks in the final difference Fourier synthesis were 0.60 and -0.37 e⋅Å-3. Final atomic coordinates are reported in Table , and significant bond parameters are given in Table .

IR Spectra. In addition to the characteristic bands of bpm at 2967 cm-1 (νC - H) and at 1520, 1456, 1396, 1337, 1280, and 1220 cm-1 (pyrazolyl ring), very intense bands due to the azido groups appear at 2102 cm-1 (νasym), 1328 cm-1 (νsym), and 602 and 614 cm-1 (δ). The peak at about 2100 cm-1 was slightly broad.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 IR Spectra. In addition to the characteristic bands of bpm at 2967 cm-1 (νC - H) and at 1520, 1456, 1396, 1337, 1280, and 1220 cm-1 (pyrazolyl ring), very intense bands due to the azido groups appear at 2102 cm-1 (νasym), 1328 cm-1 (νsym), and 602 and 614 cm-1 (δ). The peak at about 2100 cm-1 was slightly broad.

elements.content: Description of the Structure. An ORTEP plot of the basic unit and a view of the one-dimensional chains of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n are shown in Figure and Figure . The crystal structure consists of neutral chains of Mn(II) ions alternately linked by two EO (end-on) parts [Mn(1)−N(11) 2.216(3), Mn(1)−N(11a), 2.254(3) Å] and two EE (end-to-end) parts [Mn(1)−N(14) 2.231(4), Mn(1)−N(16a), 2.239(4) Å]. Coordination around the manganese atoms consists of N atoms from bpm ligands in the form of a cis distorted octahedron. The EO bridging azides, which are quasi-linear [N(11)−N(12)−N(13) 178.8(4)°], deviate slightly from the plane, and their angles are slightly larger than the value reported for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n [176.6(8)°]. The Mn(1)−N(11)−Mn(1a) angle in the EO mode is 102.9(1)°, similar to the results (100−105°) obtained for this kind of bridging ligand2,7 and larger than the value for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n [101.0(2)°]. The two Mn−N−N bond angles related to the end-on azido bridges are asymmetrical [Mn(1)−N(11)−N(12) 125.6(2)° and Mn(1a)−N(11)−N(12) 122.3(3)°]. The Mn(1)···Mn(1a) distance is 3.496(4) Å (end-on azido bridges), and the Mn(1)···Mn(1b) distance is 5.484(3) Å (end-to-end azido bridges). For the EE bridges, the Mn(1)−N(14)−N(15) angle is 129.1(3)° and the Mn(1b)−N(16)−N(15) angle is 134.2(3)°. The torsion τ angle between the mean plane of Mn(1)−N(14)−N(15)−N(16) and Mn(1b)−N(16)−N(15)− N(14) for a chair configuration4c is 41.1°, and the dihedral δ angle between the least-squares plane defined for the six nitrogen atoms of the EE bridging azides and the N(14)−Mn(1)−N(16a) plane4c is 20.5°.
elements.clean_text: Description of the Structure. An ORTEP plot of the basic unit and a view of the one-dimensional chains of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n  are shown in Figure  and Figure . The crystal structure consists of neutral chains of Mn(II) ions alternately linked by two EO (end-on) parts [Mn(1)-N(11) 2.216(3), Mn(1)-N(11a), 2.254(3) Å] and two EE (end-to-end) parts [Mn(1)-N(14) 2.231(4), Mn(1)-N(16a), 2.239(4) Å]. Coordination around the manganese atoms consists of N atoms from bpm ligands in the form of a cis distorted octahedron. The EO bridging azides, which are quasi-linear [N(11)-N(12)-N(13) 178.8(4)°], deviate slightly from the plane, and their angles are slightly larger than the value reported for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n  [176.6(8)°]. The Mn(1)-N(11)-Mn(1a) angle in the EO mode is 102.9(1)°, similar to the results (100-105°) obtained for this kind of bridging ligand2,7 and larger than the value for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n  [101.0(2)°]. The two Mn-N-N bond angles related to the end-on azido bridges are asymmetrical [Mn(1)-N(11)-N(12) 125.6(2)° and Mn(1a)-N(11)-N(12) 122.3(3)°]. The Mn(1)⋅⋅⋅Mn(1a) distance is 3.496(4) Å (end-on azido bridges), and the Mn(1)⋅⋅⋅Mn(1b) distance is 5.484(3) Å (end-to-end azido bridges). For the EE bridges, the Mn(1)-N(14)-N(15) angle is 129.1(3)° and the Mn(1b)-N(16)-N(15) angle is 134.2(3)°. The torsion τ angle between the mean plane of Mn(1)-N(14)-N(15)-N(16) and Mn(1b)-N(16)-N(15)- N(14) for a chair configuration4c is 41.1°, and the dihedral δ angle between the least-squares plane defined for the six nitrogen atoms of the EE bridging azides and the N(14)-Mn(1)-N(16a) plane4c is 20.5°.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on a polycrystalline sample in the range 300−5 K with a SQUID magnetometer, and the results are shown in Figure . The applied magnetic field was 3000 G. For the complexes, the χM values increase as the temperature decreases, reaching a maximum at about 35 K, and then decrease on cooling to 5 K. The χM T value at room temperature is 4.10 cm3·K·mol-1, which is smaller than the expected value for an uncoupled manganese(II) ion and is close to the value observed for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n . The magnetic susceptibility data were interpreted on the basis of a theoretical model for the alternating ferromagnetic−antiferromagnetic S = 5/2 chain. In addition, to obtain the satisfactory results at low temperature, a Weiss constant (ϑ) was introduced to account for interchain interactions in the solid state. Following the model and fixing g to the expected value of 2.0 for manganese(II), we obtained a very satisfactory fit of the data at 5−300 K:  J 1 = 15.7 cm-1, J 2 = −67.6 cm-1, ϑ = −3 K; R is defined as ∑[(χM T)obs − (χM T)calc]2/∑[(χM T)obs]2 and is found to be 3.5 × 10-4.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Properties. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on a polycrystalline sample in the range 300-5 K with a SQUID magnetometer, and the results are shown in Figure . The applied magnetic field was 3000 G. For the complexes, the χM values increase as the temperature decreases, reaching a maximum at about 35 K, and then decrease on cooling to 5 K. The χM T value at room temperature is 4.10 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, which is smaller than the expected value for an uncoupled manganese(II) ion and is close to the value observed for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n . The magnetic susceptibility data were interpreted on the basis of a theoretical model for the alternating ferromagnetic-antiferromagnetic S = 5/2 chain. In addition, to obtain the satisfactory results at low temperature, a Weiss constant (ϑ) was introduced to account for interchain interactions in the solid state. Following the model and fixing g to the expected value of 2.0 for manganese(II), we obtained a very satisfactory fit of the data at 5-300 K: J 1 = 15.7 cm-1, J 2 = -67.6 cm-1, ϑ = -3 K; R is defined as ∑[(χM T)obs - (χM T)calc]2/∑[(χM T)obs]2 and is found to be 3.5 × 10-4.

elements.content: Plots of χM T (○) and χM (▵) of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n versus T. Solid lines represent the best theoretical fits.
elements.clean_text: 3  Plots of χM T (○) and χM (▵) of [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n  versus T. Solid lines represent the best theoretical fits.

elements.content:
Selected Structural and Magnetic Parameters for the Alternating One-Dimensional Chain System

M···M (Å) J (cm-1) compd M−N−M (deg) EO EE M−N−N (deg) τ (deg) δ (deg) EE EO α ref [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n 101.0 3.455 5.343 131.1 41.1 22.7 −11.9 10.0 1.2 4a a 127.3 −6.3 2.5 2.5 4d a [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n 102.9 3.496 5.484 129.1 41.1 20.5 −63.7 15.7 4.2 this work 134.2 [Ni(bipy)(N3)2] n 101.5 3.248 5.117 118.2 35.2 −2.6 26 0.1 4d 129.9 [Ni(dmen)(N3)2] n 100.5 3.350 5.247 130.9 8.4 −120 20 6 12 101.2 3.272 132.9 37 3.2 102.9

a  The same compound.

It is very interesting to compare the structures and magnetic properties with those reported for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n which is structurally analogous. For both complexes [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n and [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n , given the different Mn−N−Mn angles (102.9 and 101.0°, respectively) for the EO coordination mode, the J 1 value of 15.7 cm-1 for the former is greater than the J 1 value for the latter (13.8 cm-1). On the other hand, to consider the relation between δ and the superchange J 2 parameter for the EE coordination model in which the torsion angles are the same (41.1°), the antiferromagnetic coupling should be decreased for the larger δ value (J 2 = −67.6 cm-1, δ = 20.5° for the former; J 2 = −17.0 cm-1, δ = 22.7° for the latter). The results compared with other experimental values for alternating-chain complexes are summarized in Table . The α value, defined as the alternation parameter, [|J EE/J EO|], indicates that the difference in the magnitudes of the magnetic interactions through azido ligands is large.
elements.clean_text: It is very interesting to compare the structures and magnetic properties with those reported for [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n  which is structurally analogous. For both complexes [Mn(bpm)(N3)2] n  and [Mn(bipy)(N3)2] n , given the different Mn-N-Mn angles (102.9 and 101.0°, respectively) for the EO coordination mode, the J 1 value of 15.7 cm-1 for the former is greater than the J 1 value for the latter (13.8 cm-1). On the other hand, to consider the relation between δ and the superchange J 2 parameter for the EE coordination model in which the torsion angles are the same (41.1°), the antiferromagnetic coupling should be decreased for the larger δ value (J 2 = -67.6 cm-1, δ = 20.5° for the former; J 2 = -17.0 cm-1, δ = 22.7° for the latter). The results compared with other experimental values for alternating-chain complexes are summarized in Table . The α value, defined as the alternation parameter, [|J EE/J EO|], indicates that the difference in the magnitudes of the magnetic interactions through azido ligands is large.

elements.content: In conclusion, the relationships presented may be deduced from the structural data and the magnetic properties available:  two end-on bridging azido ligands favor ferromagnetic interaction, and a relation between J and δ exists where larger δ is more effective in transfering ferromagnetic interactions, which is consistent with the results based on the density functional approach. The antiferromagnetic interactions should decrease as the torsion angles increase, which indicates that the torsion angle is the factor controlling the antiferromagnetic coupling and which is in excellent agreement with the EHMO results.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, the relationships presented may be deduced from the structural data and the magnetic properties available: two end-on bridging azido ligands favor ferromagnetic interaction, and a relation between J and δ exists where larger δ is more effective in transfering ferromagnetic interactions, which is consistent with the results based on the density functional approach. The antiferromagnetic interactions should decrease as the torsion angles increase, which indicates that the torsion angle is the factor controlling the antiferromagnetic coupling and which is in excellent agreement with the EHMO results.
